title: It's all in the mix.
summary: Should I wait to buy a five-year CD? Is it too late to invest in gold? Will emerging markets bounce back? These are the sort of questions we ask, especially at times like this, when the markets' direction seems so uncertain.
tag-2: Should I wait to buy a five-year CD? Is it too late to invest in gold? Will emerging markets bounce back? These are the sort of questions we ask, especially at times like this, when the markets' direction seems so uncertain.
tag-3: But there are two big problems. First, these questions are mighty tough to answer, because it means peering into an extremely cloudy crystal ball. Second, such questions suggest we're too focused on buying the "right" investments and we may be missing the big picture.
tag-4: What to do? Try taking a step back--and focusing on your asset allocation, which is your portfolio's basic mix of stocks, bonds, cash investments and alternative investments. Cash investments include things like savings accounts and Treasury bills, while the alternative-investments category can encompass a variety of investments, including real estate, gold, commodities and hedge funds.
tag-5: Your basic asset mix will likely be a key driver of a portfolio's risk and return. The more you invest in stocks, the higher your potential long-run return--but also the greater the chance you will suffer severe losses.
tag-6: Indeed, your asset allocation will probably have a far bigger impact on your returns than the individual investments you select. For instance, in a rising stock market, someone who is heavily invested in stock-market investments--even ones that prove to be mediocre performers--will likely fare better than another investor who is mostly in certificates of deposit, no matter how carefully selected those CDs are. Conversely, when the stock market tumbles, folks who are largely invested in stocks--even supposedly conservative stocks--will probably lose far more than those who stick mostly with CDs.
